content: What type of legitmate reason would an active duty sailor need to with hold their ID from a civilian viewing it? Has anyone ever heard of a security reason behind the answer to this question (such as holding a certain level of clearance).
reply: What type of legitmate reason would an active duty sailor need to with hold their ID from a civilian viewing it? Has anyone ever heard of a security reason behind the answer to this question (such as holding a certain level of clearance).
title: Military ID question?

content: Yes. There are those Active duty sailors that are assigned to "Black Operations". On the back of their military ID Cards they have a stamp with the black letters "BO" on it. This is highly classified and not for civilian eyes or anyone else who does not have a need to know. We have a member on these boards who was in this unit but is now retired. He goes by the name Scottj50. Ask him about these sailors.

content: Back in the 80's, in Germany, terrorists would kill soldiers just to get their ID card. It happened many times.

title: Military ID question?

content: quote: Originally posted by azmax64: Back in the 80's, in Germany, terrorists would kill soldiers just to get their ID card. It happened many times. Yep,I remember when they set of a car bomb on Ramstien AFB back in the fall of 1985. It really sucked. It seemed you always had to watch your back when walking down the streets of W.Germany. Another guy around the same time near where I was stationed at got the crap beat out of him from a German who was dressed as a U.S. soldier. I think it was near Gelnhausen. Is this legal? I don't know,but its fun isn't?!

content: quote: Originally posted by QuestionsAnswers: What type of legitmate reason would an active duty sailor need to with hold their ID from a civilian viewing it? Has anyone ever heard of a security reason behind the answer to this question (such as holding a certain level of clearance). There is personal/legal/sensitive information on any kind of legal ID and a whole lot of thieves around who would like to see it just to use it. If you don't have a legal reason, it's none of your business. Rubber-necking/gawking doesn't constitute a good reason - Wandering and Wondering
